dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, my gosh, wait. Did you see this? The Olympics, they're like, really actually doing it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, my gosh, wait. Did you see this? The Olympics, they're like, really actually doing it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I mean, uh, it's pretty wild, right? But, like, they just announced overseas spectators are a no-go.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I mean, uh, it's pretty wild, right? But, like, they just announced overseas spectators are a no-go.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Overseas spectators will be prohibited from attending the Summer Olympics in Tokyo, the games' organizing committee announced Saturday...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, what? No tourists? But, like, people bought tickets years ago! What about all that travel planning?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, what? No tourists? But, like, people bought tickets years ago! What about all that travel planning?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Right, exactly. The organizing committee, uh, they've banned them. It's really to kinda ease Japanese citizens' concerns about COVID, you know? Doctors there are super worried.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, exactly. The organizing committee, uh, they've banned them. It's really to kinda ease Japanese citizens' concerns about COVID, you know? Doctors there are super worried.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...a move they hope will mitigate the concerns of Japanese citizens over the risk that the games will seed Covid-19 outbreaks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Concerns? They were concerned like, last year! So, who even decided this? Was it just Tokyo, or...?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Concerns? They were concerned like, last year! So, who even decided this? Was it just Tokyo, or...?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, no, it was a joint decision. Like, Tokyo organizers, national and local governments, even the International Olympic Committee. Everyone basically.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, no, it was a joint decision. Like, Tokyo organizers, national and local governments, even the International Olympic Committee. Everyone basically.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Tokyo Organizing Committee made the decision jointly with national and local governments in Japan and the International Olympic and Paralympic Committees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so, uh, tickets? Are those just, like, gone? Because I remember hearing numbers, like, a lot of tickets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so, uh, tickets? Are those just, like, gone? Because I remember hearing numbers, like, a lot of tickets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, organizers say 600,000, but sources say it's closer to, uh, 1.2 million overseas tickets. They'll refund the tickets, but not your flights or hotels.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, organizers say six hundred thousand, but sources say it's closer to, uh, one point two million overseas tickets. They'll refund the tickets, but not your flights or hotels.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the organizers, approximately 600,000 tickets were sold overseas, although the Associated Press reported that number is closer to 1 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: No way! Not the flights? People are gonna be furious! That's, like, thousands of dollars for some people, just gone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No way! Not the flights? People are gonna be furious! That's, like, thousands of dollars for some people, just gone.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: I know, right? Several travel agencies are actually threatening, like, legal action already. It's a mess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? Several travel agencies are actually threatening, like, legal action already. It's a mess.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, like, the Japanese people, they're really that against it, even after it was postponed?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, like, the Japanese people, they're really that against it, even after it was postponed?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, totally. Like, over 85% in a recent poll said it should be postponed again or just canceled altogether. Even the athletes, some of them are, uh, uneasy about the safety.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, totally. Like, over eighty five percent in a recent poll said it should be postponed again or just canceled altogether. Even the athletes, some of them are, uh, uneasy about the safety.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: About 80% of Japanese believe the games, which are scheduled to begin in July, should be postponed again or canceled altogether, according to a survey by national broadcaster NHK.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: But, um, what about people who do go? Like, domestic spectators. Will it just be, like, an empty stadium?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But, um, what about people who do go? Like, domestic spectators. Will it just be, like, an empty stadium?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Well, they're still figuring that out. But early talks suggest, like, a 30% capacity maximum, for social distancing. So, yeah, pretty sparse.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, they're still figuring that out. But early talks suggest, like, a thirty percent capacity maximum, for social distancing. So, yeah, pretty sparse.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Man. And the torch relay, isn't that, like, starting soon? That feels, uh, risky, given all this.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Man. And the torch relay, isn't that, like, starting soon? That feels, uh, risky, given all this.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: It actually starts, uh, this Thursday in Fukushima, goes for four months, 10,000 runners. And yeah, there are already concerns about the safety of those torchbearers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It actually starts, uh, this Thursday in Fukushima, goes for four months, ten thousand runners. And yeah, there are already concerns about the safety of those torchbearers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The torch relay for the games will begin Thursday in Fukushima Prefecture and will last four months, with roughly 10,000 runners traversing the country.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, they're lifting the state of emergency, but still, like, banning spectators and everyone's worried? It just feels like, uh, they're trying to make it happen no matter what.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, they're lifting the state of emergency, but still, like, banning spectators and everyone's worried? It just feels like, uh, they're trying to make it happen no matter what.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Earlier this week, Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga announced the government planned to lift the state of emergency in Tokyo on Sunday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. It's a huge commitment, you know? But the optics are, uh, definitely a challenge for them right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. It's a huge commitment, you know? But the optics are, uh, definitely a challenge for them right now.
